query: What are some of the available and effective non-lethal actions to manage human-primate conflict?
relevant_summary: Based on the available evidence, several non-lethal methods have been studied for managing human-primate conflict. For crop-raiding primates, changing to crops less palatable to primates (action 1439) has been proposed, though no effectiveness studies were found. Using loud-speakers to broadcast primate alarm calls (1447) or sounds of potential threats like barking dogs and gunshots (1446) have been proposed but lack effectiveness evidence. Humans chasing primates using random loud noise (1449) reduced crop raiding by orangutans in Indonesia and returned gorillas to protected forest areas in Democratic Republic of Congo. Using chili as a deterrent (2492) has shown mixed results with elephants but no specific primate evidence is available. GPS/VHF tracking devices on problem troops to provide early warning to farmers (1443) has been proposed but not studied. Diversionary feeding (2323) reduced nuisance behavior by black bears in two USA studies, though this was not specifically tested on primates. Translocation approaches have been studied for other mammals (2341, 2336) but specific evidence for primates is lacking, with general translocation showing mixed results including high return rates and continued nuisance behavior.

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Eight studies evaluated the effects of using non-lethal methods to deter carnivores from attacking humans. Three studies were in the USA, two were in Australia, one was in the USA and Canada, one was in Austria and one was in Bangladesh.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Survival (1 study): A study in Bangladesh found that when domestic dogs accompanied people to give advance warning of tiger presence, fewer tigers were killed by people.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)
OTHER (8 STUDIES)
Human-wildlife conflict (8 studies): Two studies, in the USA and Canada, found that pepper spray caused all or most American black bears and grizzly bears to flee or cease aggressive behaviour. One of these studies also showed that tear gas repelled half of American black bears. Two studies in the USA and Austria found that grizzly/brown bears were repelled by rubber bullets or by a range of deterrents including rubber bullets, chasing, shouting and throwing items. A study in the USA found that hikers wearing bear bells were less likely to be approached or charged by grizzly bears than were hikers without bells. A replicated, controlled study in Australia found that ultrasonic sound deterrent units did not affect feeding location choices of dingoes. A study in Bangladesh found that domestic dogs accompanying people gave advance warning of tiger presence, enabling people to take precautionary actions. A study in Australia found that a motorised water pistol caused most dingoes to change direction or speed or move ≥5 m away, but sounding a horn did not."
}

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Two studies evaluated the effects of using non-lethal measures to prevent bats from accessing fruit in orchards to reduce human-wildlife conflict. The studies were in Madagascar and Mauritius.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)
OTHER (2 STUDIES)    

Human-wildlife conflict (2 studies): Two replicated, controlled studies (including one randomized study) in Madagascar and Mauritius found that using an organic deterrent spray, hanging plastic flags in trees, or covering individual tree branches with nylon net bags reduced damage to lychees caused by Madagascan flying foxes or Mauritius fruit bats. One of the studies found that ringing bells in lychee trees deterred most Madagascan flying foxes."

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)

Uptake (1 study): A site comparison study in Slovenia found that 22-63% of the estimated annual energy content of the diet of brown bears comprised provided diversionary food.

OTHER (2 STUDIES)

Human-wildlife conflict (2 studies): Two before-and-after studies (one also a site comparison) in the USA found that diversionary feeding reduced nuisance behaviour by black bears."

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)
OTHER (2 STUDIES)

Human-wildlife conflict (2 studies): A study in the USA found that almost half of the translocated ‘nuisance’ black bears returned to their capture locations. A review of studies in the USA and Canada found that black bears translocated away from sites of conflict with humans were less likely to return to their capture site if translocated as younger bears, over greater distances, or across geographic barriers."
}

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)
OTHER (2 STUDIES)
Human-wildlife conflict (2 studies): Two studies, in the USA, found that lacing foodstuffs with substances that induce illness led to these foods being avoided by coyotes and black bears."
}

{
  "action_id": "2492",
  "action_title": "Use chili to deter crop damage by mammals to reduce human-wildlife conflict",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Seven studies evaluated the effects on elephants of using chili to deter crop damage to reduce human-wildlife conflict. Four studies were in Zimbabwe, two were in Kenya and one was in India.

KEY COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)
OTHER (7 STUDIES)

Human-wildlife conflict (7 studies): Five of seven studies (including four replicated and two before-and-after studies), in Zimbabwe, Kenya and India, found that chill-based deterrents (chili-spray, chili smoke, chili fences and chili extract in a projectile, in some cases along with other deterrents) repelled elephants at least initially, whist two studies found that chili smoke (and in one case chili fences) did not reduce crop raiding."
}

{
  "action_id": "2336",
  "action_title": "Translocate problem mammals away from residential areas (e.g. habituated bears) to reduce human-wildlife conflict",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Eleven studies evaluated the effects of translocating problem mammals (such as bears) away from residential areas to reduce human-wildlife conflict. Six studies were in the USA, two were in Canada, one was Russia, one was in India and one was in Romania.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (6 STUDIES)

Survival (6 studies): A controlled study in the USA found that grizzly bears translocated away from conflict situations had lower survival rates than did non-translocated bears. A replicated study study in the USA found that fewer than half of black bears translocated from conflict situations survived after one year. Two of three studies (two controlled), in the USA, found that after translocation away from urban sites, white-tailed deer survival was lower than that of non-translocated deer. The third study found that short-term survival was lower but long-term survival was higher than that of non-translocated deer. A study in Russia found that most Amur tigers translocated after attacking dogs or people did not survive for a year after release.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)
OTHER (6 STUDIES)

Human-wildlife conflict (6 studies): Five studies (including one controlled and two replicated studies), in the USA and Canada, of brown/grizzly or black bears translocated away from residential areas or human-related facilities, found that at least some returned to their original capture location and/or continued to cause nuisance. In two of the studies, most returned to their capture area and one black bear returned six times following translocation. A before-and-after study in India found that leopards translocated away from human-dominated areas, attacked more humans and livestock than before-translocation. A controlled study in Romania found that translocated brown bears occurred less frequently inside high potential conflict areas than outside, the opposite to bears that had not been translocated."
}

query: What are the most effective community-led actions for reducing illegal hunting of primates?
relevant_summary: The most effective community-led actions include implementing community control of patrolling, banning hunting, and removing snares, which showed positive results in multiple studies across different regions. In the Democratic Republic of Congo, community control was more effective at reducing illegal bushmeat hunting, including primates, compared to nearby national parks. Similarly, in Cameroon, no incidents of gorilla poaching occurred over three years after implementing community control and monitoring of illegal activities, and in Nigeria, there were more gorillas and chimpanzees in areas managed by community conservation organizations. Implementing local no-hunting community policies or traditional hunting bans also proved effective. Studies from China, Democratic Republic of Congo, Belize, Cameroon, and Nigeria showed that primate populations increased following the implementation of local hunting bans, with very few snub-nosed monkeys killed annually in areas where wildlife killing was forbidden, and populations of gorillas, black howler monkeys, drills, and Sclater's monkeys all increasing after hunting prohibitions were established. Strengthening or reinstalling traditional taboos that forbid the killing of primates was found to be effective, with Laotian black crested gibbons occurring at higher densities in areas protected by local hunting taboos compared to sites without such taboos.

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

One review found that very few snub nosed monkeys were killed annually at a site in China where it is forbidden to kill wildlife.
One controlled study in the Democratic Republic of Congo found that a lowland gorilla population increased after the implementation of a local hunting ban.
One before-and-after study in Belize found that an introduced black howler monkey population increased over time in an area where hunting was controlled, alongside other interventions.
One before-and-after study in Cameroon found that a drill population increased in numbers after being protected by a hunting ban, alongside other interventions.
A study in Nigeria found that populations of Sclater’s monkey increased in an area where hunting of the species was prohibited by local taboos."
}

{
  "action_id": "3681",
  "action_title": "Engage local communities in conservation activities",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Six studies evaluated the effects on reptile populations of engaging local communities in reptile conservation. One study was in each of the Philippines, Mozambique, Brazil, Costa Rica, Australia and Colombia.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (5 STUDIES)

Abundance (1 study): One site comparison study in Brazil found that areas where community-based management of fishing practices was implemented had a higher abundance of river turtles than areas with no community-based management.
Reproductive success (3 studies): Two before-and-after studies (including one site comparison study) in Mozambique and Costa Rica found that after involving the community in monitoring of nesting activity, fewer sea turtle eggs were lost to poaching than before projects began. One replicated, before-and-after study in Australia found that when management of a saltwater crocodile egg harvest passed to an Indigenous management group, the number of eggs collected and hatching success of those eggs was lower than when it was run by an external company.
Survival (2 studies): One study in the Philippines found that after rural community members were paid a small incentive to protect Philippine crocodile sanctuaries combined with an education and awareness campaign, fewer crocodiles were killed than before community engagement. One before-and-after study in Mozambique found that during a community-based turtle monitoring project no killing of adults was recorded.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)
OTHER (1 STUDY)

Human behaviour change (1 study): One replicated study in Colombia found that in areas where communities were engaged in conservation initiatives relating to turtles, more people reported changing consumption habitats and fewer people reported using turtles for food compared to in areas with no initiatives, however, stated rates of hunting, buying and selling of turtles remained similar."
}

{
  "action_id": "2423",
  "action_title": "Provide education programmes to improve behaviour towards mammals and reduce threats",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Two studies evaluated the effects of providing education programmes to improve behaviour towards mammals and reduce threats. One study was in South Africa and one was in the USA.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Abundance (1 study): A before-and-after study in South Africa found that educating ranchers on ways of reducing livestock losses, along with stricter hunting policies, increased leopard density.
Survival (1 study): A before-and-after study in South Africa found that educating ranchers on ways of reducing livestock losses, along with stricter hunting policies, reduced leopard mortalities.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)
OTHER (1 STUDY)

Human behaviour change (1 study): A replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that visiting households to educate about the danger of garbage to black bears did not increase use of wildlife-resistant dumpsters."
}

{

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)         

Behaviour change (1 study): One before-and-after study in Ghana found that after providing education about the ecological roles of bats fewer hunters intended to hunt bats in the future."
}

query: Which anti-poaching measures are most beneficial for primate populations?
relevant_summary: Based on the evidence from action documents, several anti-poaching measures have demonstrated benefits for primate populations: Regular anti-poaching patrols have shown positive effects, with studies in Rwanda and Democratic Republic of Congo finding that gorilla populations increased when regular patrols were implemented alongside other interventions. A study in Uganda found that no gorillas were killed over a 21-month period when anti-poaching patrol numbers increased. Training anti-poaching ranger patrols has proven beneficial, with studies in Uganda showing no gorilla deaths over 21 months after game guard training. In Rwanda, areas where game guards received training saw increased numbers of immature gorillas. Providing better equipment to anti-poaching ranger patrols has shown positive results, with studies in DRC and Rwanda finding increased gorilla populations. Implementing monitoring surveillance strategies has demonstrated benefits, with Nigeria studies finding increased observations of gorillas and chimpanzees after implementing law enforcement and monitoring systems. Regular removal of ground snares has shown some benefits, including increased mountain gorilla numbers in patrolled areas.

POPULATION RESPONSE (7 STUDIES)

Abundance (6 studies): Two studies, in Thailand and Iran, found more deer and small mammals and more urial sheep and Persian leopards close to ranger stations (from which anti-poaching patrols were carried out) than further from them. query: What are the documented outcomes of using different legal protection strategies, such as protecting primate species versus protecting their habitat?
relevant_summary:
Documented outcomes show mixed results for both primate species legal protection and habitat protection strategies. For species-specific legal protection (Action ID 1524): A before-and-after study in India found rhesus macaque populations increased over 17 years following an export ban. However, studies in Thailand and India showed primate populations declined despite legal protection. In Malaysia, most introduced Müller's Bornean gibbons died despite legal protection, and in Cameroon, drill populations declined at four of five sites despite protection.

For habitat legal protection (Action ID 1578): Studies in China showed primate numbers increased or no more individuals were killed after areas received legal protection. A study in Kenya found Tana River red colobus monkey and crested mangabey numbers decreased despite legal protection. A study in China showed Hainan gibbon numbers increased by 34% over nine years after habitat protection. In Brazil, most golden lion tamarins did not survive over seven years despite being in a legally protected area, though they reproduced and surviving offspring partly compensated for adult mortality. Studies in Republic of Congo and Gabon found most central chimpanzees and lowland gorillas reintroduced to legally protected areas survived over 4-5 years. A study in Mexico found black howler monkeys in protected areas had lower stress levels than those in unprotected forest fragments.

Overall, the evidence suggests habitat protection may show more positive outcomes than species-specific protection alone, with multiple studies documenting population increases or improved welfare measures when habitats are legally protected.

Four studies evaluated the effects of legally protecting habitat for marine and freshwater mammals. One study was in each of the North Atlantic Ocean (Portugal), the South Pacific Ocean (New Zealand), the North Sea (UK) and the Port River estuary (Australia).

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (4 STUDIES)

Abundance (2 studies): One before-and-after study in the North Atlantic Ocean found that a population of Mediterranean monk seals increased during eight years after the islands they inhabited were legally protected. One before-and-after study in the North Sea found that a population of bottlenose dolphins was estimated to be a similar size before and after part of its range was protected.
Survival (2 studies): One before-and-after study in the South Pacific Ocean found that the survival rate of Hector’s dolphins was higher after a coastal area was legally protected than before. One before-and-after study in the Port River estuary found that after the area became legally protected a similar number of Indo-Pacific bottlenose dolphin strandings were recorded compared to before protection, but the number of strandings caused by humans decreased.

{
  "action_id": "3831",
  "action_title": "Legally protect habitat",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Ten studies evaluated the effects on butterflies and moths of legally protecting habitat. Six studies were in the UK and one was in each of Australia, Singapore and Ireland and the USA. Three of the studies used data from the same national monitoring scheme across different years.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

Richness/diversity (3 studies): One replicated, site comparison study in Singapore found that protected primary or secondary forest reserves had a higher species richness of butterflies than unprotected forest fragments. One replicated, paired, site comparison study in Ireland reported that raised bogs protected as Special Areas of Conservation (where restoration had sometimes taken place) had a similar species richness of moths to unprotected bogs. One replicated, site comparison study in the UK found that, in the first three years after protection as Sites of Special Scientific Interest (SSSI), woodland, grassland and heathland sites lost a similar proportion of 29 threatened butterfly species to unprotected sites.

POPULATION RESPONSE (8 STUDIES)

Abundance (7 studies): Three of five site comparison studies (including four replicated studies and one before-and-after study) in the UK and Ireland found that sites protected as National Nature Reserves or Sites of Special Scientific Interest (SSSI) (in one case also managed by coppicing), or surrounded by SSSIs, had a higher abundance of heath fritillary, all butterflies and 30/57 species of butterfly than unprotected sites. However, one of these studies only found the result using one of two sets of sites. The other two studies found that grasslands protected as National Nature Reserves or SSSIs and raised bogs protected as Special Areas of Conservation had a similar total abundance of moths, and change in abundance of chalkhill blue butterflies, to unprotected sites. However, one of these studies found mixed results for individual moth species. One replicated, site comparison study in the USA found that, at sites with the highest levels of protection, abundances of Karner blue, frosted elfin and Persius duskywing did not change over time, whereas they decreased at sites with lower levels of protection. One replicated, site comparison study in the UK found that protected grasslands assessed as being in “Favourable” habitat condition had worse population trends for 4/8 butterfly species but better for 1/8 species than grasslands in “Unfavourable” condition. One study in Australia reported that after a grassland was designated as a local reserve, populations of golden sun-moth and pale sun-moth persisted for at least four years.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

query: What interventions can mitigate the impacts of mining and dam construction on primate populations?
relevant_summary: Several interventions have been proposed to mitigate the impacts of mining and dam construction on primate populations, though most lack empirical evidence for their effectiveness. For dam construction, creating or preserving primate habitat on islands before dam construction has been suggested (Action 1455). For mining operations, establishing no-mining zones in or near watersheds to preserve water levels and water quality (Action 1452), using 'set-aside' areas of natural habitat for primate protection within mining areas (Action 1453), and minimizing ground vibrations caused by open cast mining activities (Action 1451) are potential mitigation strategies. Reintroducing primates in groups has shown mixed results, with some studies showing population increases while others found declining populations after reintroduction (Action 1567). Translocating mammals away from development sites has been attempted, with limited success as some animals return to their capture sites (Action 2517). Other suggested interventions include restoring habitat corridors (Action 1583), certifying mines and marketing their products as 'primate friendly' (Action 1454), and reusing old roads rather than building new ones (Action 1463). However, evidence for the effectiveness of these interventions is largely lacking, with most actions classified as having 'no evidence' regarding their impacts on primate populations.

tools_called.args: {"query_string": "mining dam construction primate populations mitigation interventions", "k": 10}

Two studies in Madagascar and India found that primate populations persisted 4-55 years after reintroduction in groups, alongside other interventions.
Seven studies in Brazil, French Guiana, Madagascar, and South Africa found that a minority of primates survived for at least 15 weeks to seven years after reintroduction in groups, alongside other interventions. Seven studies in Belize, Brazil, French Guiana, Madagascar, and South Africa found that a majority of primates survived after between two and thirty months.
One study in Madagascar found that introduced black-and-white ruffed lemurs Varecia variegata had similar diets to individuals in a wild population after reintroduction in groups, alongside other interventions.
One study in The Gambia found that a population of introduced chimpanzees increased 25 years after reintroduction in groups, alongside other interventions. Four studies in Guinea, Liberia and the Republic of Congo found that the majority of chimpanzees survived for at least two to five years, after reintroduction in groups, alongside other interventions.
Two before-and-after studies in Gabon and the Republic of Congo found that the majority of western gorillas survived for at least nine months to four years, after reintroduction in groups, alongside other interventions.
One controlled study in Indonesia found that all Sumatran orangutans survived for at least three months after reintroduction in groups, alongside other interventions."
}

Six studies evaluated the effects on butterflies and moths of thinning trees within forests and woodland. Three studies were in the USA and one was in each of Côte d’Ivoire, Finland and the Czech Republic.

Community composition (1 study): One site comparison study in Côte d’Ivoire found that rarer species of fruit-feeding butterfly were less frequently caught in a forest managed by thinning than in an unmanaged, naturally regenerating forest.


Richness/diversity (6 studies): Four studies (including two replicated, paired, controlled, before-and-after studies) in the USA and Finland found that one, two or four years after management, coniferous woodland which had been thinned, along with either prescribed burning, mulching or nearby felling, had a greater species richness of butterflies, or butterflies, diurnal moths and bumblebees combined, than either unmanaged woodland or before management. One site comparison study in Côte d’Ivoire found that a forest managed by thinning had a similar species richness and diversity of fruit-feeding butterflies to an unmanaged, naturally regenerating forest. One site comparison study in Côte d’Ivoire found that a forest managed by thinning had a similar abundance of fruit-feeding butterflies to an unmanaged, naturally regenerating forest.

query: What are the most beneficial community-based strategies for primate conservation?
relevant_summary: Education and awareness programs have shown positive impacts on primate conservation. Educating local communities about primates and sustainable use in Cameroon led to increased drill populations when combined with another intervention (Action ID: 1563). Multimedia campaigns using theatre, film, print media, and discussions have demonstrated significant benefits, including 61-138% increases in black howler monkey numbers over 3-13 years in Belize alongside other interventions (Action ID: 1571). These campaigns also improved attitudes and knowledge about tamarins in Brazil and Colombia, informed large numbers of people about lowland gorillas in the Republic of Congo, and led to the apparent cessation of poaching for diademed sifakas and black and white ruffed lemurs in Madagascar after distributing conservation books in local primary schools. Community involvement in conservation management has mixed but encouraging results. Involving local communities in management showed benefits for black howler monkeys in Belize, with numbers increasing over 13 years when combined with other interventions (Action ID: 1565). A community-based monitoring scheme in Cameroon successfully stopped gorilla poaching incidents when implemented alongside other conservation measures. However, some proposed community-based strategies lack supporting evidence. Paying farmers to cover the costs of non-harmful strategies to deter primates (Action ID: 1429), compensating farmers for produce loss caused by primates (Action ID: 1428), employing hunters in the conservation sector to reduce their impact (Action ID: 1484), creating buffer zones around protected primate habitat (Action ID: 1577), and installing billboards to raise primate conservation awareness (Action ID: 1566) all have no evidence available to assess their effectiveness.

query: What are the documented outcomes of various veterinary interventions on the survival and health of wild or reintroduced primate populations?
relevant_summary: Documented outcomes of veterinary interventions on wild or reintroduced primate populations show mixed survival results across species and intervention types. Pre-release veterinary screens, when combined with other interventions, showed variable outcomes: most reintroduced golden lion tamarins and 90% of Müller's Bornean gibbons did not survive despite pre-release screening, while most black lion tamarins survived over four months, and translocated orangutans typically survived capture and three months post-translocation. Mountain gorilla populations increased by 168% over 41 years with continuous health monitoring by veterinary staff alongside other interventions. Treatment of parasites showed mixed results: most golden lion tamarins did not survive despite treatment, but 70% of reintroduced chimpanzees survived for at least 3.5-5 years and some populations increased. Quarantine protocols before release showed variable effectiveness with most golden lion tamarins and black-and-white ruffed lemurs not surviving over five years, though more than 80% of reintroduced gorillas survived over ten years. Treatment of sick or injured primates demonstrated similar variability: most golden lion tamarins died despite treatment availability, most chimpanzees survived 1-5 years with some populations increasing, and most orangutans survived capture and release. Overall, veterinary interventions alone showed inconsistent survival improvements, with outcomes varying significantly by species, intervention type, and implementation alongside other management strategies.

tools_called.args: {"query_string": "veterinary interventions primate populations survival health reintroduced wild", "k": 10}

query: As an alternative to providing domestic meat, what other actions can logging companies take to reduce hunting pressure from their employees, and is there evidence for their effectiveness?
relevant_summary: Several actions can be taken by logging companies as alternatives to providing domestic meat to reduce hunting pressure from their employees. These include ceasing or reducing hunting incentive payments, introducing alternative income sources, and reducing team sizes to include only employees without family members. There is evidence that ceasing or reducing payments to cull mammals can be effective - a before-and-after study in Sweden and Norway found that fewer brown bears were reported killed after the removal of financial hunting incentives. However, there is no evidence available for the effectiveness of most other alternative actions. These include providing sustainable alternative livelihoods through fish or domestic meat farms, introducing alternative food sources to replace wild meat, and reducing forestry team sizes to include employees only without family members. One study showed that introducing alternative income sources (in this case a turtle management project) led fishers to cease turtle fishing activities, suggesting this approach may have broader applicability for reducing hunting pressure from forest workers.

query: What actions can be taken within agricultural land in tropical regions to create or maintain primate habitat?
relevant_summary: Based on the evidence found, several actions can be taken within agricultural land in tropical regions to create or maintain primate habitat. These include creating natural habitat islands within agricultural land (Action 1425), planting nesting trees or shelter for primates within agricultural fields (Action 1431), and retaining existing nesting trees or shelter for primates within agricultural fields (Action 1430). Additionally, retaining or planting native trees and shrubs amongst crops through agroforestry practices (Action 963) has shown benefits for bat populations, with studies in Mexico, Columbia, Costa Rica, and Tanzania finding that shaded plantations with varied tree cover supported more species and higher abundances compared to unshaded monocultures. However, it should be noted that no direct evidence was found for the effects of the primate-specific actions on primate populations, as these actions have not yet been studied quantitatively.

query: What are the documented benefits and negative impacts of implementing tourism projects for primate conservation?
relevant_summary: The documented evidence on tourism projects for primate conservation shows mixed results. Benefits include population increases for several species, with mountain gorilla numbers increasing by 168% over 41 years in Rwanda, Uganda and Congo when sick/unwell researchers and visitors were not allowed to visit gorillas (Action 1546), and numbers increasing at multiple sites after tourist projects were initiated alongside other interventions (Action 1512). Black howler monkeys in Belize increased by 138% over 13 years after tourism project implementation (Action 1512), and most central chimpanzees reintroduced in Republic of Congo survived over five years when local communities received monetary benefits (Action 1509). Negative impacts include a Chinese study showing Tibetan macaques experienced increased stress levels and 100% infant mortality in some years when an intensive tourism project included food provisioning and range restrictions (Action 1512). A Madagascar study found population declines for two lemur species after tourism project implementation, though one species increased (Action 1512). Additionally, a Kenya study showed decreases in Tana River red colobus and crested mangabey populations despite tourism projects (Action 1512).

query: What are the effects of implementing veterinary and health-related interventions for wild or reintroduced primate populations?
relevant_summary: The effects of implementing veterinary and health-related interventions for wild or reintroduced primate populations are mixed. Veterinary screening before reintroduction/translocation shows variable outcomes: studies found that most reintroduced golden lion tamarins, Müller's Bornean gibbons, black-and-white ruffed lemurs, and some orangutans did not survive long-term despite pre-release veterinary screens, while other studies found most reintroduced chimpanzees, black lion tamarins, Bornean agile gibbons, and olive baboons survived various time periods post-release. Continuous health monitoring with permanent veterinary presence led to significant population increases, with mountain gorilla populations monitored by vets increasing by 168% over 41 years. Quarantine protocols also show mixed results: most reintroduced golden lion tamarins, black-and-white ruffed lemurs, and some orangutans did not survive despite pre-release quarantine, while more than 80% of reintroduced gorillas that underwent quarantine survived over ten years. Health programs for local communities and hunter education about disease transmission risks show no evidence of effectiveness studies available to assess their impact on primate populations.

query: Besides government-led anti-poaching patrols, what community-based alternative actions can be implemented to reduce primate hunting?
relevant_summary: Community-based alternatives to government-led anti-poaching patrols for reducing primate hunting include: 1) Implementing community control of patrolling, banning hunting and removing snares, which has proven more effective than national park management with no gorilla poaching incidents over three years in Cameroon, 2) Establishing local no-hunting community policies or traditional hunting bans, supported by local taboos that protect primates, 3) Strengthening traditional taboos that forbid killing primates, 4) Engaging local communities in conservation activities and monitoring programs, 5) Promoting sustainable alternative livelihoods to replace hunting, and 6) Involving local communities in primate research and conservation management schemes.

query: To mitigate conflict between humans and primates in urban and residential areas, what are the most effective actions to reduce primates' access to human food sources?
relevant_summary: The most evidence-supported approach is implementing a 'no-feeding of wild primates' policy, as one study found that several Japanese macaque populations declined in size and productivity after limiting and prohibiting food provisioning [1502]. Additionally, putting up signs to warn people about not feeding primates has shown effectiveness, with a review study finding that aggressive interactions between Japanese macaques and humans declined after prohibiting tourists from feeding monkeys [1507]. For physical barriers, preventing mammals from accessing potential wildlife food sources through electric fencing and electric shock devices has demonstrated effectiveness, with studies showing these methods successfully excluded American black bears from bird feeders and stone martens from buildings [2346]. Other recommended actions include installing 'primate-proof' garbage bins [1505], removing human food waste that may serve as food sources for primates [1561], not allowing people to consume food within areas where primates can view them [1508], and implementing enforcement notices to require appropriate waste management [2345].

query: To minimize disease transmission from humans in ecotourism settings, what suite of actions can be implemented?
relevant_summary: To minimize disease transmission from humans in ecotourism settings, evidence-based actions include ensuring visitors and researchers are up-to-date with vaccinations and healthy before allowing them to visit wildlife (Action 1546), with one study showing mountain gorilla populations increased by 168% over 41 years while implementing health checks for visitors. Wearing protective equipment such as face-masks to prevent transmission of viral and bacterial diseases to primates (Action 1537) has shown positive results, contributing to the same 168% increase in mountain gorilla populations over 41 years. Regular disinfection of clothes and boots (Action 1547) was also associated with increased mountain gorilla populations. Limiting the time that researchers and tourists are allowed to spend with habituated animals (Action 1539) and maintaining safety distances from habituated animals (Action 1538) have been implemented with positive conservation outcomes. Additional measures include wearing gloves when handling primate food or tool items (Action 1548) and removing human food waste that could serve as food sources for primates (Action 1561), though these specific interventions lack direct evidence of effectiveness. Implementing quarantine protocols for people arriving and leaving sites (Action 1540) and establishing health programs for local communities (Action 1557) are additional recommended measures, though evidence for their effectiveness is currently lacking.

query: What is the evidence for creating or restoring primate habitat within agricultural or otherwise fragmented landscapes?
relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents shows limited but positive results for primate habitat creation and restoration in fragmented landscapes. One before-and-after study in Belize found that black howler monkey numbers increased by 138% over 13 years after protecting forest patches along property boundaries and across cleared areas (Action ID: 1581). The same study found that protecting a forest corridor also contributed to this population increase (Action ID: 1580). However, for many specific interventions within agricultural landscapes, no evidence was found. No studies were identified that evaluated maintaining, restoring or creating habitat connectivity on farmland (Action ID: 2381), creating natural habitat islands within agricultural land (Action ID: 1425), retaining or planting nesting trees/shelter for primates within agricultural fields (Action IDs: 1430, 1431), or restoring habitat corridors (Action ID: 1583). This indicates significant research gaps in documenting the effectiveness of primate habitat interventions within agricultural settings.

query: Within logging concessions, what are the documented effects of alternative harvesting methods to clear-cutting, such as selective logging?
relevant_summary: Selective logging and reduced impact logging (RIL) show several documented effects compared to clear-cutting in logging concessions. Studies from USA and Canada found some species were more abundant in selectively-logged forests while others were less abundant, with one study showing no consistent differences between selective harvesting and clearcuts (Action 331). For butterflies and moths, reduced impact logging had mixed effects: Brazilian forests managed with RIL had similar community composition and species richness to primary forest but different from pristine forest, with intermediate intensity RIL showing higher butterfly abundance than high or low intensity (Action 3867). Moth species richness in shelterwood harvesting recovered faster than after clearcutting, while thinning showed higher species richness than clearcutting (Action 3871, 3868). For bats, reduced impact logging had smaller effects on abundance than conventional logging, though activity varied by species (Action 989). Primate studies showed variable results: low intensity selective logging had higher primate densities than high intensity logging in Sierra Leone, but similar densities in Uganda studies, with lemur numbers increasing following selective logging in Madagascar (Action 1485). Three reptile studies found mixed effects on lizard abundance with selective logging intensity, but similar overall reptile abundance compared to clearcutting/thinning combinations (Action 3637).

query: What are the documented benefits of conservation strategies that involve local community education and management participation?
relevant_summary: Documented benefits of conservation strategies involving local community education and management participation include: Increased wildlife populations - Himalayan brown bear populations increased with community park management involvement (2395), drill primate numbers increased following education programs (1563), and black howler monkey populations increased 61-138% over 3-13 years with multimedia education campaigns (1571). Improved habitat quality - Community-based mangrove restoration in India increased high-quality mangrove forest area while decreasing degraded forest area (3390). Reduced illegal activities - Community-based wetland management in Senegal resulted in fewer fines for illegal activities like settlement and grazing (3390). Enhanced species protection - Poaching of diademed sifakas and black and white ruffed lemurs ceased after conservation books were distributed in local primary schools (1571), and hoolock gibbon numbers increased 66% over five years with education programs (1571). Better resource management - Community-based fisheries management areas had more abundant scallop populations compared to protected or recreational areas (2242), and fewer farmers removed large carnivores when engaged in community-based land management (2395). Improved conservation behavior - Students' conservation behavior toward Asian horseshoe crabs significantly increased after education programs (2281), and education programs improved attitudes and knowledge about tamarins (1571). Increased awareness - Large numbers of people were informed about lowland gorillas through multimedia campaigns (1571), and visitors' knowledge about primates increased after education programs (1571).

query: What is the evidence on the effectiveness of non-lethal deterrents to prevent primates from entering agricultural areas?
relevant_summary: One controlled, replicated, before-and-after study in Indonesia found that using noise deterrents combined with tree nets reduced crop raiding by orangutans (Action 1449). A study in the Democratic Republic of Congo found that chasing gorillas and using random noise resulted in gorillas returning from plantations to areas near protected forest (Action 1449). Studies on loud noise deterrents for mammals show mixed results - five of six studies found that loud noises reduced crop damage by white-tailed deer, black-tailed deer, and elephants when animals were in the vicinity, while three studies found that regularly sounding loud noises did not repel European rabbits or white-tailed deer (Action 2460). However, there is no evidence available for several primate-specific deterrents: studies on planting favored crops away from primate areas, using unpalatable buffer crops, and changing to less palatable crops all show 'no evidence' status, meaning no studies have directly tested these interventions for primates (Actions 1440, 1438, 1439). Evidence for chili-based deterrents exists for elephants but not specifically for primates (Action 2492).

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Seven studies evaluated the effects on elephants of using chili to deter crop damage to reduce human-wildlife conflict. Four studies were in Zimbabwe, two were in Kenya and one was in India.

KEY COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)
OTHER (7 STUDIES)

Human-wildlife conflict (7 studies): Five of seven studies (including four replicated and two before-and-after studies), in Zimbabwe, Kenya and India, found that chill-based deterrents (chili-spray, chili smoke, chili fences and chili extract in a projectile, in some cases along with other deterrents) repelled elephants at least initially, whist two studies found that chili smoke (and in one case chili fences) did not reduce crop raiding."

  "action_id": "2460",

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Ten studies evaluated the effects of using loud noises to deter crop damage by mammals to reduce human-wildlife conflict. Three studies were in the USA, two were in Zimbabwe and Kenya and one each was in the UK, Namibia, and India.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)
OTHER (10 STUDIES)

Human-wildlife conflict (10 studies): Five of six studies (including two controlled, one replicated and two before-and-after studies), in the USA, Namibia, Kenya and India, found that loud noises activated when an animal was in the vicinity reduced or partially reduced crop damage or crop visits by white-tailed deer, black-tailed deer (when combined with using electric shock collars) and elephants. The other study found that using loud noises (along with chili fences and chili smoke) did not reduce crop-raiding by African elephants. Three studies (including two controlled studies), in the UK and the USA, found that regularly sounding loud noises did not repel European rabbits or white-tailed deer. Two replicated studies, in Zimbabwe, found that, from among a range of deterrents, African elephants were repelled faster from crop fields when scared by firecrackers or by a combination of deterrents that included drums."
